title: exclusive micro aggressions list mistake admits cambridge vice
story: Cambridge’s vice-chancellor has moved to quell a free speech revolt by issuing a statement to academics saying the university’s publication of a “micro-aggressions” list was a mistake.Prof Stephen Toope wrote to the entire staff body to explain that aspects of its new reporting website - which was launched last week but then taken offline days later following its exposure in The  - had been included “in error”.His intervention came after 25 Cambridge dons openly rebelled over the website, signing a joint letter to this newspaper warning that academics must have “unfettered freedom of speech”.Last week, a list of potential offences were published by Cambridge on a new website on which academics and students could anonymously report “inappropriate” behaviour.It stated that academics could be committing a “micro-aggression” if they raise an eyebrow, give backhanded compliments, turn their backs on certain people, or refer to a woman as a girl.On Monday, the university performed an abrupt about-turn and took the website down.Two days later Prof Toope told staff: “Unfortunately, the supporting website contained material that was published in error. The erroneously published content included definitions and examples of behaviours that might be reportable.”He said that “some of those definitions and examples went beyond the policies discussed and agreed by colleagues” in the run-up to the website’s launch, adding: “That material should not have been there, and its publication was a mistake.”The vice-chancellor insisted that he “unambiguously” wants to “bolster the university’s reputation for enquiry and vigorous debate”.Prof Toope went on to say that Cambridge is “rightly known for offering people the space to think and to challenge conventions”.He said that the “mis-step” created the impression that the university might be “unduly” constraining freedom of expression.Dons described the personal letter from the vice-chancellor as a surprising development, with one adding: “It is unusual to have such a long email on one topic that in fact concedes the cock-up”.Another academic said: “It is obviously pretty embarrassing that the university has been planning this major new policy for over a year and they have had to do a U-turn within a week of it being launched.“It raises questions about how anything like this could have come within a mile of being approved by senior people at the university and published on their website.”He said it is “hard to believe” the material was published by mistake, “given how much work went into it”.Dr Arif Ahmed, a lecturer in philosophy at Gonville and Caius welcomed the vice-chancellor’s climb down, but said it is important to “get to the bottom” of what happened.“I think anything that involves anonymous reporting that is used for anything other than statistical process is so clearly contrary to ordinary rules of process,” he said.Dr James Orr of Cambridge’s Divinity Faculty said: “The vice-chancellor should be commended for doing the right thing.“But until the university's managers recognise that the free expression of many reasonable and plainly lawful beliefs can always be subjectively - and therefore unverifiably - construed as causing psychological harm, these sorts of crises will continue to occur.”The website had been created as part of a “Change the Culture” initiative that includes a series of policies and resources aimed at “clarifying expectations” about behaviour.A list of examples of micro-aggressions was provided on the website, including asking someone “where are you really from?” and misgendering a person, especially if they have already shared their pronouns.   This is the second free speech victory Cambridge dons have claimed in the past six months.On Thursday, Cambridge re-published its Report and Support website but the list of “micro-aggressions” had been taken down, as had its definition of racism. The website says that students and staff can make “named reports” about inappropriate behaviour of others but explained that the anonymous reporting option is now under review. It explained that a working group has been convened to decide on the future of this aspect of the site. In December, academics prevailed after voting down an attempt by university chiefs to force them to be “respectful of the erse identities of others”.Three amendments, put forward by academics who said they wanted to safeguard free speech at the 800-year-old university, were voted through, leading the rebel dons to claim they had “won by a landslide”.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: left rabid dog life like ordinary belarusians trapped country
story: Europe and Britain have moved to ban flights to and from Belarus to punish Alexander Lukashenko for effectively hijacking a Ryanair flight in order to arrest a dissident journalist. But many Belarusians who oppose Mr Lukashenko and have suffered under his rule fear they are about to become even more isolated. Maxim, a 33-year-old artist currently living at an artists residence in Vienna, was due to fly back home to Minsk next month but now is not sure how he would get back.“Minsk airport used to be the only way to get out of the country,” said Maxim, a 33-year old artist who was meant to fly back to Minsk after completing a residency in Vienna next month. “The EU ban for Belavia is a direct blow against ordinary people and civil society. They have isolated and left us with a rabid dog,” he said, referring to the president of 26 years. The regime doesn’t give a damn about Belavia because they have been slapped with visa bans as it is.”In a list of sanctions announced on Tuesday, the European Council called on member states to close their airspace and airports to Belarusian carriers, and stop their own airlines from flying to or over Belarus. Latvia and Poland (along with non-EU members Britain and Ukraine) have already banned their own airlines from flying to and from Belarus, resulting in cancelled flights to Warsaw and Riga. The measures have been welcomed by Belarusian opposition leaders including Svetlana Tsikhanouskaya, the exiled former presidential  candidate who many Belarusians believe was the legitimate winner of August's election. Speaking to the European Parliament on Thursday, she urged MEPs to stick to the proposed sanctions and not be tempted to return to a softly-softly policy. “The EU approach of gradually elevating pressure on the Lukashenko regime hasn't managed to change its behaviour and only led to a growing sense of impunity and massive repressions,“ she said. But many ordinary Belarusians, including those sympathetic to the opposition, have expressed dismay. The Belarusian government imposed stiff restrictions on crossing the country’s land borders citing fears of Covid-19 that Mr Lukashenko otherwise routinely dismisses as insignificant, making it almost impossible to drive or take the train into neighbouring Poland and Lithuania. And the recent arrests of several Belarusian dissidents in Russia, which has a visa free regime with Belarus and has previously served as an escape route for opponents of Mr Lukashenko, has also left many wary of travelling via Moscow. Many fleeing Mr Lukashenko’s brutal crackdown on the opposition have in recent months taken the short flight to Warsaw or Vilnius instead, and they now fear that door closing.“People on both sides of the border found themselves in a cage,” said Volha Neskladovskaya-Tereshkova, 28, who moved to Poland with her family in March.Everyone opposed to the Lukashenko regime “has been waiting for harsh sanctions for so long: But now that it happened, the sanctions are not really against the regime but against ordinary people,” she said. Ms Neskladovskaya-Tereshkova is typical of thousands of opposition-leaning Belarusians who have sought refuge in Europe following the terrifying and indiscriminate crackdown Mr Lukashenko unleashed after a disputed elections in August. Her husband, an IT specialist, was grabbed by riot police at an election-night protest and was repeatedly beaten and humiliated in custody before he was released three days later. Investigators declined to open a criminal probe when he complained about the beatings. The couple and their toddler left the country when secured a Polish work visa. Now, she says, she has no idea when she will next see her parents. She’s also not sure what to do about the family corgi, which is still in Minsk and which her brother was meant to bring to Warsaw in the coming weeks. “We’d probably have to do it via Russia but it’s not easy flying with a dog.”“It feels like a trap.  Land borders are closed and now planes won’t fly. In the past, if you were in danger, you could relocate to Poland or Lithuania, and the flights were cheap, fast and open to us, said  Marina Sokolova, a 46-year old freelance journalist in Minsk. Nonetheless, she insisted she could see the point of the sanctions and said she could bear them - provided all these steps contribute to change in Belarus.I’m a journalist and many of my friends are now in prison and what are our inconveniences caused by the ban in comparison to their suffering in prison. It is a double edged sword. We are trapped but we understand that this is one step to our freedom,” she said.  The anger is also spilling onto social media, with many wondering how isolation will harm the regime. Talks around passenger flights tofrom Belarus are a celebration of human indifference, Andrey Vozyanov, a Minsk based musician, wrote on Facebook. Belarusians whom I know had long feared of being sealed off, but few expected it coming from outside.European diplomats are certainly aware of the issue. German officials raised the possible impact on members of the Belarusian opposition trying to get out of the country during the talks that led up to Tuesday's statement on sanctions. And a French proposal to sever all land transportation links with Belarus was shot down by other nations who considered it too drastic and likely to hurt ordinary people. The full closure of EU airports to Belavia, the national carrier most Belarusian travellers rely on, will only come into effect after ministers and bureaucrats hammer out the legal details, which could take weeks. Minsk airport continued to schedule Belavia flights to and from EU destinations including  Amsterdam, Milan, Tallin, Vienna and Warsaw remained scheduled on Wednesday and Thursday. Flights will continue to Russia and most other former Soviet states remain unaffected, as well as major non-European hubs including Istanbul. Belavia currently flies non-stop from London Gatwick to Minsk three times weekly on an Embraer 195. A total of 13 flights from London to Minsk (one way) are scheduled to depart in June 2021, according to Cirium, a company that collates aviation industry data. Andrei Sannikov, a former presidential candidate and opposition leader who fled Belarus after being beaten and jailed in 2011, said concerns about the consequences for ordinary people were legitimate. But he argued that the measures were necessary and marked a long overdue recognition that more than two decades of trying to engage with Mr Lukashenko's regime had failed. “Yes I am worried about the impact on ordinary people, but I have not heard anyone really complaining about it so far. When I speak to people, they generally say they are willing to endure a little pain if they can finally get rid of this psychopath,” he said by telephone from Warsaw, where he now lives. The main thing is that Europe has finally realised Lukashenko is a threat to everyone. They previously tried to treat Belarus as a humanitarian issue, not as a security issue, and that did not work, he said. Ms Neskladovskaya is not so sure. “Europe wants to ensure safety for its own citizens: but who’s going to ensure our safety? she said. People got shut out and they have no idea how to get out of the country if they need to.”More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: matt hancock backbenchers flock health secretarys aid spartacus
story: On Wednesday, Dominic Cummings described his work-day from hell: Covid cases surging, emergency COBRA meetings derailed by begging requests to join Trump’s bombing campaign of Iraq – and most shocking of all - Number 10’s media operation going into meltdown over the reputation of a Jack Russell.Most of us would be hard-pushed to imagine so awful a day – but then again, most of us aren’t Matt Hancock. Given the epic monstering he endured at Cummings’s hands on Wednesday, it was almost a surprise to see him still standing in the Commons, bloodied but unbowed.Caught in the crosshairs, he attempted a Churchillian call to arms – though this being Matt, it was overlaid with trademark Hancockian schmaltz. He heaped praise on Our NHS and warmly thanked the “volunteers who stood in cold car parks with a smile”.“We have come together, and we have overcome!”, he finished, flopping back dramatically on the green benches.Jonathan Ashworth, Hancock’s mild-mannered opposite number, usually seems a bit too polite for the Westminster swamp. Today, even he came out keen to slash and burn – though with his cherubic features and reedy voice, the effect was underwhelming, like watching your pet hamster attempting a powerplay to commandeer the seedbox.“Is he ashamed that he promised a protective shield around care homes, and over 30,000 care home residents have died?”, piped Ashworth solemnly.The Health Secretary looked cowed. Any minute now his bottom lip was going to wobble. But suddenly reinforcements arrived in the reassuring form of Jeremy Hunt – former health secretary, select committee chair and classic Head Boy material. Like a protective older brother, he defended poor Matt from the sixth-form bully who’d stolen his dinner money and spread nasty stories about him in the locker-room.The Tory faithful whinnied approvingly, but it was not over yet.Martyn Day of the SNP demanded a full and immediate public inquiry, Yasmin Qureshi asked about corporate manslaughter and Munira Wilson doubled down on care home deaths. Legions of opposition MPs surrounded the Health Secretary, drawn to the Cummings standard.Then, following Jeremy Hunt’s lead, the Tory backbenchers linked arms and formed a defensive phalanx around him. One by one, they stood up, in a blue-rosetted version of Spartacus, demonstrating their solidarity in ever-more sycophantic ways.“When it comes to the Health Secretary, I’m a fan”, said Mark Logan, quoting an approving constituent and plugging an article he had written in the Secretary of State's defence.“Yeahyeahyeah!” snarled the Tory combatants.Much of the love-bombing emanated from the West Country. Selaine Saxby thanked him for visiting North Devon district hospital and condemned the ‘flip-flopping’ opposition. Cherilyn Mackrory went one further, not just celebrating his trip to the Royal Cornwall Hospital in Truro but posing a hardball question: “Can my right honourable friend assure me that he will ignore unsubstantiated Westminster gossip, and stay focused on delivering the vaccination rollout?”“I’m Matt Hancock!” “I’m Matt Hancock!” they cried.It resembled siege warfare. The Opposition trebuchet would lob a few Cummings projectiles at the keep. Meanwhile Matt or one of his backbenchers would retaliate with missiles of their own, usually praise for the vaccination rollout, or use of the word ’unprecedented’, which was deployed in unprecedented quantities, even for these unprecedented times.The congenial back-slapping atmosphere occasionally intensified into heavy-petting, but Matt swelled and his confidence blossomed.At the evening press conference later, the transparency-loving Health Secretary swerved queries about care home deaths with a familiar tactic repeating the same waffling platitudes until it was time for the next question.“Every day we are unwavering in our focus to protect life”, he trilled, on auto-pilot, using phrases only a character in a Steven Spielberg film – or a Minister who knows he’s lived to fight another day – would be bold enough to articulate.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: might soon live 150 good thing
story: “Immortality dashed,” announced the headline in this newspaper, “but humans could live to be 150.” It says something about the unrealistic expectations of the modern human that living for one and a half centuries should be presented as something of an anti-climax.For years now there have been rumours that scientists, funded by Silicon Valley billionaires, were on the brink of solving death altogether. But a large-scale study of elderly volunteers in America and the UK has concluded that even the best-maintained body is doomed to “progressive functional decline”. Our biological resilience cannot extend beyond 120-150 years: “the absolute limit of the human life”.Still – 150 years. That sounds good to me. Enough time to really get stuck in, but with a distant deadline to concentrate the mind. Like doing a PhD in life, instead of bluffing your way through the GCSE.Although the average global life has already more than doubled – from 47 in 1950, to 73 today – it’s still a struggle to fit everything in. In fact, living longer has made us more slow-moving, particularly when it comes to the big decisions: leaving the parental home, finding a long-term mate, becoming parents ourselves.I was 36 when I had the first of my three children, almost 14 years ago. If I were a global statistic from 1950, I’d be dead already. As it is, I sometimes find myself staring at the ceiling in the insomniac hours, calculating all the things I may miss out on because of this late start.If my children reproduce as sluggishly as me, and if I die in my seventies, like my father, I may never get to meet any of my grandchildren.It’s not the babies per se that I feel sad about it’s the thought that I won’t be able to accompany my children on this part of their adventure.There are, it must be admitted, obvious drawbacks to extending our lifes. The chances are we wouldn’t get much in the way of extra youth. By far the bulk of our additional years would be spent in a condition of extreme senectitude. What’s the point of meeting your descendants if you can only wave at them wanly from your pickling vat?It would be awful for the planet, too. John K Davis, an American philosophy professor, has run demographic models to see what extending our lives to 150 would do to the world. His research found that, even if the birth rate was limited to two children per woman, the global population would reach 21 billion by the end of this century: 10 billion more than currently projected. Mass famine, on the heels of climate disaster, would surely follow.For the sake of our grandchildren, then, we should not strive to meet them. But how can we resist? Life really does feel so short as it is.American pharmacists are reporting a surge in sales of teeth-whitener, as the country prepares to relax its guidance on mask-wearing. Make-up, party clothes, deodorant and hair-removal cream are also booming.What a bore! The one enjoyable aspect of this pandemic has been allowing myself to go entirely to seed. I haven’t worn make-up, put on high heels or even weighed myself for over a year. My body is so hairy I hardly need clothes to stay warm.I could happily stay like this – fat, furry and comfortable – forever. Or at least until I’m 150.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: shock poll puts far right afd ahead german regional elections
story: A shock poll has put the far-Right Alternative for Germany party (AfD) in first place ahead of regional elections in eastern Germany next week.An AfD victory in the state of Saxony-Anhalt would be a major upset and the worst possible start to Angela Merkel’s Christian Democrats' (CDU) campaign ahead of September’s general elections.A survey by the respected pollster Insa gave the AfD a slim lead, on 26 per cent, just ahead of the CDU on 25 per cent, ahead of the June 3 regional vote.The findings are unlikely to signal a national resurgence for the AfD — Saxony-Anhalt, in the former communist east, is something of an outlier and the party is polling badly at a national level.But an AfD victory in the final regional elections before September’s national vote would be a bitter blow for rival parties — and particularly for the CDU, which has won the state in every election since 2002.It could further shake confidence in Armin Laschet, the party’s candidate to succeed Mrs Merkel, who is stepping down following September's elections after 15 years in power.Mr Laschet, already struggling with low approval ratings, was not the grassroots choice to lead the CDU into September’s election, and he can little afford a loss now.Even if the AfD wins in Saxony-Anhalt, it is unlikely to be able to form a regional government. The poll has it well short of a majority, and all the other parties have ruled out going into coalition with it.Instead a rival coalition is likely form around the CDU in order to keep the far-Right party out of power.Reiner Haseloff, the regional CDU leader, has made it clear any form of cooperation with the AfD is a “red line” the party will not cross.“The AfD has no coalition partners, and cannot govern without them and against the CDU,” Hermann Binkert, the head of Insa, said.There was good news for the Green Party, which is set to more than double its vote from 2016 in Saxony-Anhalt, according to the Insa poll, which had it in fourth place on 11 per cent.The party has traditionally struggled in the former communist east, and a good result would be seen as evidence it can now compete in every region of Germany. The Greens briefly led the national polls this month, but they have slipped back to second, on 22 per cent behind the CDU on 26 percent.The AfD is currently in fifth place nationally on 11 per cent, short of the 12.5 per cent the party won in 2017’s general election.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeRishi Sunak claimed David Cameron was not given any special attention from the Treasury, despite dozens of cosy chats and messages between him and senior officials and ministers. The Chancellor claimed his department’s contact with the former PM did “not occupy a lot of our overall time”, and that “it was important to look at this regardless of who was raising it with us.” MPs were left gobsmacked as Mr Sunak complained that having to declare details of lobbyists’ contact with officials might mean firms are less likely to engage with government. And a fresh row emerged over the publication of texts from a top Treasury official to former PM David Cameron as he lobbied officials on behalf of a doomed lender. Top treasury official Sir Tom Scholar refused to allow texts he sent to the David Cameron to be handed over to the Treasury Select Committee, which scrutinises the work of Mr Sunak’s department. Mr Cameron contacted Sir Tom, pleading in vain for the Government to prop up financier Greensill Capital as the Covid- pandemic took hold. Mr Cameron released his side of the chummy conversation - which he signed off Love DC. But the Treasury said Sir Tomaposs replies had been wiped, after his password was entered incorrectly on his official phone. In one of Mr Cameron’s messages to Sir Tom on March , the former PM appeared to predict a Bank of England interest rate cut five days before it was announced.  Mr Cameron wrote: “Never quite understood how rate cuts help a pandemic. Officials are legally barred from disclosing market sensitive information about changes to interest rates. Mr Cameron claimed he had been talking about an already announced VAT rate cut. And speaking to the Committee today, Sir Tom said he could not remember the subject of the discussion, but suggested it might have been to do with an emergency rate cut in the United States. But askedhe would allow Mr Cameron to provide his copy of his messages to the Committee, he refused - saying any release of the information should be controlled by the Treasury through Freedom of Information disclosures. Such disclosure could take weeks, and would allow the Treasury to redact the messages before they were released to the public. The messages that we were talking about were generated by me in on an official government device in the course of official government business, Sir Tom said. And I think itaposs appropriate that that be treated like any other part of official government business, and disclosure would have been governed through the Freedom of Information act. Sir Tom told the Committee his phone gets accidentally wiped about once a year, adding: It tends to happen after the password has been changed, which youaposre required to do at regular intervals. Both Treasury officials and Mr Sunak claimed Mr Cameron’s lobbying had been unsuccessful, and had not taken up much time. Charles Roxburgh, second permanent secretary to the Treasury, defended the Treasury’s nine meetings with the firm’s representatives. He told the Committee Mr Sunak “did not spend a lot of time on this, and I did not spend a lot of time on this, because I too was working on a lot more time-consuming and intense situations at the time, Mr Roxburgh met several times with Greensill at a time when the Government was scrambling to respond to the Covid- pandemic. After a few meetings the Treasury declined Greensillaposs attempts to be part of the Bank of Englandaposs Covid Corporate Financing Facilityscheme. Mr Sunak claimed increasing transparency on Government lobbying would make firms “reluctant” to engage with ministers, which he said would be “disappointing and damaging to the policymaking process. “If they feel that every communication with government is available to the public, they might be reluctant to engage,” he said.FOLLOW USMirrorPoliticsFollow @MirrorPoliticsCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnDavid CameronThe TreasuryBank of EnglandBanksCivil servantsInterest ratesPolitics

And it will only get better as the long weekend draws on with higher temperatures and more sunshine. While Friday will see some spots of rain in the west most areas will stay dry and temperatures will rise to above  C in some regions. Particularly in the west but many eastern areas will still be dry and bright. He said the morning would see patchy pain in western regions with apossome uncertaintyapos of how far it would creep into north west and south west England. title: centre young offenders were brutally
story: NewsCentre where young offenders were brutally abused to detain women seeking asylumPriti Patel’s cruel plan for the Medomsley Detention Centre in Country Durham opens a new chapter of suffering after a brutal double betrayal as survivors of abuse want to see the buildings torn down and refugee campaigners were promised a new approach to womens detentionmirrorShareCommentsByRos Wynne JonesReal Britain columnistMaryam Qaiser:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsDavid Alan Brown was violently abused at Medomsley Detention Centre in  " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeThe Medomsley Detention Centre site is barely visible from the road, and shunned by locals. Its ­red-brick buildings are haunted by its brutal past as an experiment in Margaret Thatcher’s “short, sharp shock”. For decades, the facility for young, first-time offenders, was the scene of brutal, sadistic detention, where  to -year-olds were sexually and physically abused – for which members of staff were eventually convicted. Now, Home Secretary Priti Patel has a new plan for the abandoned buildings near Consett, County Durham. A “prison-style” detention and “removal centre” for up to  women seeking asylum. The news comes as a blow to Medomsley’s survivors who want to see the buildings torn down. It is also a betrayal of refugee campaigners promised a new approach to women’s detention, at a time when concerns are growing over Home Office failures at Napier and Penally Barracks. What is your view  Have your say in the comment section  Medomsley survivor David ‘Alan’ Brown says he was sent there in  aged  for a petty crime he didn’t commit. Now a -year-old grandad, he waived his anonymity in  to give evidence against his abusers. This week, we introduced Alan to Agnes Tanoh, a refugee who is campaigning against the centre. “It is a shock, because in my opinion that place needs to be knocked down,” Alan told Agnes. “There are too many bad memories in that bad place. When I drive past or see or hear the word Medomsley, it makes me feel ill. I want to drive a crane with a big ball on the end and smash it to bits.” He shares his memories, which include being “kicked to bits” in a padded cell, “hearing bones crunch” during beatings handed out to other boys, and one boy asking him to stamp on his leg to break it, to escape a brutal PT session. Agnes, who once worked for the Ivorian MP Simone Gbagbo, we of the former president, narrowly escaped the Ivory Coast with her le in . A year earlier she was among those locked up with Mr and Mrs Gbagbo when rival politician Alassane ­Ouattara seized power following a contested election. More than , people were killed in fighting, including many of Agnes’ close friends. She was freed from prison by the UN, walked to Ghana, and fled to the UK to seek sanctuary. “I came here to save my le,” she tells Alan. “I knew the UK. I’d visited as a diplomat and sent my children to study here.” But when she asked for help, she ended up in the notorious Yarl’s Wood Detention Centre near Bedford.Like news to one of the Mirroraposs newsletters “It was so painful to be in prison again. I was taken three times to the airport to be deported. I thought death was waiting for me at the other side. I was so ­frightened, I tried to trust in God. “I finally have refugee status and am believed, after eight years repeating the same story. Why was I locked up  I still live with the stigma and pain.” At , Alan was beaten every day by Christopher Onslow, a PT instructor. He was punched in the mouth by another officer, John McGee. He knew others were being sexually abused. “They were watching us in the showers, there was something sick about the whole place,” he says. “Onslow was an animal. The weak lads, you could hear the crunch, he was hitting them so hard. It was a pure nightmare.”  Niamh Wilson of Hampson Hughes Solicitors, which represents survivors, adds: “It is shocking that these plans are even being considered. “We’ve worked with over  victims who suffered unimaginable physical and sexual abuse at Medomsley ­Detention Centre – the idea of the site being used again to imprison ­vulnerable people is appalling. I know victims we have supported agree the building needs to be torn down, not used for a further chapter of suffering.” A Home Office spokesperson said: “Immigration detention plays a crucial role in a robust immigration system and a signicant proportion of women detained are facing deportation because of criminal offences.  “The immigration removal estate is under ongoing review to ensure the Home Office has sufficient resilience, geographical footprint and capacity for the men and women it is necessary to detain for the purposes of removal, while providing value for money.” The facility at Medomsley later became Hassockfield Secure Training Centre, which closed in . It took until  for Alan to get justice. “I told the court, don’t feel sorry for these little old men – in  they were animals,” he says. “Onslow got eight-and-a-half years. I felt asI had lost eight stone getting that out of us.” Onslow, then , was found guilty of assault and wounding with intent while McGee, then , was jailed for two years and eight months for assault and misconduct in a public office. Agnes is visibly upset. “What I went through, I don’t want to happen to others who just want protection,” she says. “When they harm one lady, they harm a family, ­children. I will campaign until someone hears our cry.” Alan nods. “Fighting the ­Government is one of the hardest things you can do. They don’t listen to people like you and me. They don’t care about people like us. It took me years to get even with these people. “Never give up. Never. If you give up, they get away with it.”To sign Agnes’ petition, visit change.org and search for “women detention centre”Additional reporting Maryam QaiserFOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnPriti PatelHome OfficePrisonsCrimePoliticsImmigrationAsylum SeekersChild abuse

title: couple transform run down caravan
story: NewsCouple transform run-down caravan into dream riverside getaway for less than £,It took Nicola Harris and her husband Mark just four weekends to refit the static camper – and theyve turned it into a lavish lockdown-proof getaway for less than £,mirrorShareCommentsByRia NewmanLaurie Churchman:,  MAY NewsNicola Harris and her husband Mark spent £, transforming a caravan into an ideal holiday home " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA couple with a passion for DIY have transformed a caravan into a stunning riverside holiday home for just £,. Nicola Harris, , fell in love with the lush river views when she visited her brother in Shillingford-on-Thames, Oxfordshire, earlier this year. She and her husband Mark, , decided to buy a static caravan – and then spent under £, turning it into a dream getaway. Half the cost went towards flooring, new blinds and a plush sofa. The caravan looked a little tired when they bought it for £, earlier this year. But with just a few daysapos work, they have given the place a complete refit. Nicola said: “It was really dated, in good condition and quite clean but the décor wasn’t me at all. “I wanted a ‘fixer upper’, something I could really put my mark on. To turn the caravan into a stylish home, the couple took out the fitted sofas and side units in the living room - and then painted all the interior walls and units in the kitchen, bathroom and living room. They also removed the curtains and nets from the windows and replaced them with made-to-measure venetian blinds – and it cost just over £ for the whole van. Nicola and Mark also used stick-on metro tiles to give the kitchen and bathroom a fresher look. They scoured bargain home stores for accessories, getting their hands on lamps, mirrors and fake plants. It took just four weekends to complete the renovation. Nicola says removing the carpet was the worst job. She said: “Apparently they carpet caravans, then add the fitted furniture – so wardrobes, sofas, and even the shower cubicle had the pink carpet underneath. “I was still pulling up carpet at midnight the Sunday evening before the flooring was laid. I could have cried that night!” A local company installed the herringbone vinyl for the floor, which changed the feel of the caravan instantly, but the couple did the rest. Nicola added: “After the flooring was done, I loved seeing each room transformed with just a coat of paint and a few accessories. “I love it – every time I walk in, I smile – it’s such a lovely place to be. “I’m really looking forward to creating wonderful memories down the van with friends and family, especially now we can start socialising again.” The van is just  minutes away from the coupleaposs Oxfordshire home. They said it was important for the family to have a nearby vacation spot as lockdown restrictions ease. Nicola said: “With overseas travel restrictions still in place who knows when we will be able to travel freely again. “We have a two-week holiday booked to the Dominican in July but I’m pretty certain it will be cancelled so we will spend at least one, possibly two, of those weeks here at the van. “The caravan will also be nice for my grown-up children to use with their friends for a getaway, as we have all had holidays cancelled over the last  months. “With the van being right on the river, it really does have a holiday vibe to it.“Although we can’t guarantee the weather in England, when the sun does shine thereaposs no better place to be.She added: Itaposs made me look more at holidaying in England in the future, rather than feeling I always have to jet off somewhere for a break.”FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnDream Homes

Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA pub boss says drinkers ordering too many Pornstar Martinis is slowing down service in a frank assessment after re-opening their business. With Covid restrictions gradually being lted punters can now sit inside pubs, with beer gardens no longer the only place to grab a pint.One pub owner has spoken out to thank their customers and to open up candidly about what it has been like to run a pub after lockdown, Yorkshire Live reports. The Wentworth Arms in Mapplewell was allowed to reopen again outside in April after months of being forced to close due to coronavirus restrictions.This week owners said that they held their hands up at some mistakes as they struggled to juggle with preparing and planning how many people would visit the pub.  In an honest post, they said: Whilst we planned and prepared as best we could, weaposve had to learn and adapt as weaposve gone along.Unfortunately you donapost know what you donapost know, for example, how popular the first two weeks would be, how many staff would be required to provide service under the brand new, outside only, table service operating model and look after an unknown number of customers, never mind what the weather would do.The pub also said they sold over  Pornstar Martinis on Monday, April , which caused an issue as they take three to four minutes to make compared to less than  seconds to fill a pint. Owners said it had a big impact on speed of service. They added: We were caught out a little again last week with the popularity of food. Hands up from us for that but again you donapost know what you donapost know. For example on a normal Friday night roughly half of our tables would be just drinking. This Friday pretty much all our  tables plus beer garden tables were dining and most ordered between pm and pm. Serving  plus plates in an hour is beyond our kitchen capacity, so wait times were longer than they should have been. We accept there have been occasions in the last six weeks where weaposve got things wrong or not delivered the level of service we would want to. Thankfully most of the time everything has been to the standards we aim for and we are very grateful for our customersapos patience and understanding when it was not. Pubs are now allowing punters back inside after a further easing of coronavirus restrictions. More lockdown easing could take place at the end of June. The pub added: The last and biggest shout out goes to our awesome staff. For the last six weeks every member of staff has worked pretty much every sht they physically could, theyaposve ed the following day, put their apron and a smile on and got on with the job again. What a team! Thank you.FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnCoronavirus

Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeThe cost of digging up a cafe in the search for missing Mary Bastholm has been revealed to be £,. The excavation project was sparked after a TV crew reported finding blue material buried in the cellar in Gloucester. It was long suspected Fred West killed the teenager and could have buried her in the basement of the then Pop In cafe in . The -year-old worked at the Pop In café, where Fred was a regular, and her disappearance came at a time when he was abducting, raping and murdering girls and women in Gloucester. But on Thursday Gloucestershire Police announced the dig had been completed and no aposhuman remains or items of signicanceapos had been found.  Police have also said the mystery aposblue materialapos was a burst pipe likely caused by the drilling of the TV production company.The search started after It gained the footage by inserting a camera into a hole their crew had drilled. Assistant Chief Constable Craig Holden said initial imagery detected something blue - but on analysis was most likely detritus or debris from a burst pipe - possibly caused by the drilling. Speaking outside Gloucestershire Constabulary he said: The blue material photographed on an endocope camera by the TV production company was not identied, but we did establish it was likely to be connected to a buried pipe. That pipe [which was not blue] was recovered and excavations went beyond the original endoscope depth. We believe that the drilling may have gone through the pipe and created some sort of detritus or debris, which is what the endoscope picked up.  When we looked, we didnapost see anything blue, so what we believe is that the imagery has given the impression of something blue. Weaposve eliminated that whatever it was that could have been interpreted as blue in that imagery from our investigation. ACC Holden confirmed the cost of the excavation to the taxpayer currently stands at around £, - but could rise to £, or £,. On raising the hopes of Maryaposs family, he said: Itaposs clear to say the family had been contacted by the production company and by the owners of the café. The family were hugely supportive of the work of the production company and I completely understand and accept that the decision made back in  by the then SIO John Bennet and then subsequently the decision that was made the previous chief constable - were reasonable decisions.  The dference here is that new information had come to light that we felt was appropriate to assess. Quite rightly we were approached, new information was provided, that new information predominantly was that there was a blue material in a void within the ground underneath the café. And under careful assessment with our team of investigators and detectives and also nationally accredited experts - we brought those in to assess that information and make a determination as to whether or not there could be a body within that cellar. I believe that the proportionate way that we went about that did take account of whether or not we should search in all areas or some areas. And the guidance and advice from those experts identied the areas that we should be spending more time searching and excavating. Itaposs unfortunate that the initial work that was done through the endoscope and the drilling by the production company couldnapost guarantee that there were no human remains or nothing connected to Maryaposs disappearance. We felt a proportionate excavation was the right, appropriate and proper thing to do. Itaposs absolutely clear that our aim here was to support the family to do everything we possibly could to put Mary to rest on their behalf and I believe that was the right decision. ACC Holden added: Everybody working on this is disappointed that we didnapost find Mary - allowing her family finally to lay her to rest after over  years is absolutely the most important reason for this investigation. Our thoughts are with Maryaposs family, whose continued dignity in recent weeks, and over the many years before, has been absolutely humbling.  Iaposm now confident that Mary is not buried in the cellar of the café, and I hope that eliminating this location will bring some small comfort to her family. We have always been clear that we might not find Maryaposs remains. Sadly, that proved to be the case on this occasion. But it does not mean that we were wrong to look - the new information made it the right thing to do. Serial killer Fred, , committed suicide in prison in  while awaiting trial for  murders. His we Rose, now , was convicted of  murders in the same year and sentenced to le. West is said to have confessed to killing Mary in conversation with his eldest son, Stephen, , but never admitted it to police.FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnFred West

title: gang who exploited covid pandemic
story: NewsGang who exploited Covid pandemic to steal £k of benefits caught trying to flee UKMonika Gorska and her sister Edyta Gorska frequently opened Universal Credit accounts in the names of Polish Nationals, in order to obtain cash from the governmentmirrorShareCommentsByHayley ClarkeMilo BoydReporter:,  MAY NewsMonika Gorska and her sister were caught trying to flee the UK " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeAn organised crime gang stole hundreds of thousands by exploiting pandemic relief benefits. The group managed to seal £, from the Department for Work and Pensionsand £, from a Barking bank.Monika Gorska and her sister Edyta Gorska were arrested while trying to flee to Poland on October ,  and their mobile phones were examined, My London reported.Evidence from the DWP showed that the pair were frequently opening Universal Credit accounts in the names of Polish nationals, in order to obtain cash from the government.The multi-person group had first been discovered in February , when Santino Laskowski, , attempted to open a bank account at a branch in Barking, using someone ’s credentials and a fraudulently obtained utility bill. He was arrested at the bank, and his mobile phone was examined by Dedicated Card and Payment Crime Unit officers.  The phone was found to contain details of several fraudulently opened bank accounts in the names of others, and messages between Laskowski and Ali Tariq exchanging fraudulent bank account information. Later in February , Tariq went to a bank with a Polish man to fraudulently open an account using his details.  Tariq was arrested and officers found that the Polish man had been coerced into opening an account on behalf of Tariq for fraudulent purposes. On the very same day, bank employee Karolina Zmijewska was arrested on suspicion of committing fraud. The bank identied accounts that she had opened which matched those in Laskowski’s phone messages.  Zmijewska denied any wrongdoing when questioned, claiming she had opened the fraudulent bank accounts on behalf of a woman named Gorska. Detective constable Matt Cornell said: “This criminal gang wrongfully thought they could get away with committing £k of fraud, including by exploiting the Universal Credit scheme. “Fortunately, we were able to detect these criminals by working closely with the bank to bring them to justice. “This sentencing is a warning to those who believe they can benefit financially from fraud that they will be caught and punished.”  Will Quince, the minister for welfare delivery at the Department for Work and Pensions, added: “I welcome these sentences which show we work with partners to relentlessly pursue organised criminals who set out to fleece the taxpayer for their own gain. “I’m committed to driving down fraud in the benefits system, ensuring the welfare safety net reaches those in need, and this outcome makes clear that crime doesn’t pay.” Laskowski, , of no known address, was sentenced to two years and four months for conspiracy to defraud the UK banking industry. Tariq, , of Newham, received a two year sentence, suspended for two years, plus a -day rehabilitation course and curfew for conspiracy to commit fraud.  Zmijewska, , of Enfield, received an  month prison sentence for conspiracy to commit fraud. Monika Gorska, , resident of Poland, was handed a two and a half year prison sentence for conspiracy to commit fraud and conspiracy to supply articles for use in fraud. Edyta Gorska, a resident of Poland, received two years for committing money laundering offences.FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnDepartment for Work and PensionsBanksPrisonsCrime

title: how getting back board improved
story: AdvertorialHow getting back on board improved one mans mental healthA National Lottery-supported group helped Marc Lawler get back on his skateboard - and it’s brought his family togethermirrorShareByLaura Tait:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY AdvertorialMarc with his son Brandon at the Hook Skate Park in NottinghamStanding at the top of the ramp, Marc Lawler felt the adrenaline begin to kick in. It was  years since he had last ridden a skateboard – he’d given it up to concentrate on his job as a welder and being a dad to his first child, Jack. But passing a skateboard shop in his hometown of Nottingham, he’d felt the pull of his old hobby. Minutes later, he walked out with a brand new board under his arm. STARTING SLOWLY That was two years ago, and Marc, now , has been brushing up on his skills. “It took me a while to get back into it, but I gradually got there,” he says. “I live opposite a skate park so I could see when it was quiet and I’d time my visits for then. Marc wasn’t sure how his body would stand up to the thrills – and inevitable spills – of the sport: “I started slowly so I didn’t hurt myself, and didn’t attempt anything more complicated than just moving round on the board at first. “I wasn’t too worried about what people thought, though. One of the good things about being older is that you care less about what people think.” As he grew more confident, Marc began to share his hobby with his family.  His -year-old son, Brandon, also had a skateboard, so the pair headed to a Skate Nottingham event, where the coaches taught them tricks and techniques. “Brandon will try stunts that I’m just too cautious to do,” says Marc. “I used to skate ramps, jumping from one and landing on another but it’s too dangerous now. I might crack my head or injure my knee and I’m too old for that. My worst injury has been a rolled ankle.” Marc sticks to street-style skating, where he uses kerbs and rails to skate on. “I taught myself to skate on rails by starting on low walls and then building up,” he explains. “It can take me anything from a week to nearly a year to learn a new trick. It feels great when I can master one that I’ve been working on for ages.” While Marc can skate some impressive rails, he’s still trying to master a basic kick flip, which involves jumping up, flipping the board over and landing on it. Skate Nottingham puts on National Lottery-funded events at skate parks, workshop venues and public spaces around the city, encouraging people of all ages to give it a go. It’s just one of many good causes to have benefited from National Lottery funding, thanks to the £ million raised every week* by players. For Marc it has become a family affair as his stepson, Bill, , joined in and the trio began to explore Nottingham’s skate parks. “We decided to visit as many as possible,” says Marc. “There are such a lot of them now and they’re all really well designed. We started before lockdown but have begun to explore dferent skate parks again now that things are beginning to open up again. And thanks to the support of The National Lottery, many of these parks have the funds to be maintained and improved. Marc started to go to more Skate Nottingham events to show others that you could skateboard regardless of your age. He also began to make friends as he saw the same faces at dferent events. “I didn’t have lots of confidence and I thought I was quite shut off from other people,” says Marc. “But it’s such an inclusive pastime that I began to really feel part of the community.” Meanwhile Marc and the boys began to record the skate parks they visited, and they have ventured further afield. At the last count they had visited around  parks, going as far as Cornwall. “We’re hoping to hit the  mark but we won’t stop there,” says Marc. “It’s become a real family affair too. My elder son, Jack, has started coming along for the ride and to explore new areas, and my -year-old stepdaughter Esme wants to get some roller skates.”  FURTHER BENEFITS As well as bringing them closer as a family, there have been some other benefits too. “It really helped with my mental health over lockdown,” says Marc. “It gave me the space to take some time for myself and unwind. And it’s helped me get to know Bill better. “I’ve also noticed that Brandon is really changing the way he approaches learning new things. In the skate park, he has to stop and assess things logically and I can see that having a positive effect at school too.” How the money you raise is raising smiles In these challenging times it’s great to be able to put a smile on people’s faces. And when you play The National Lottery you’re helping people to do exactly that – whether it’s by bringing the world of the Vikings to le or driving the unique underground train in London’s Postal Museum.  Many of those who have benefited from funding have faced their own le challenges. They include Ekow Otoo, who hasn’t let multiple sclerosis stop him achieving sporting glory. He now stars in The National Lottery’s stunning new TV ad, in which he pulls off some spectacular moves in his wheelchair at a skate park. By playing The National Lottery, you raise £ million for good causes every week* – and during the pandemic, aside from the Government, no one has made a greater contribution to those affected than National Lottery players.When we all play a little, fun stuff happens. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeThe Duchess of Cambridge has kept her promise to a little who wanted to meet a princess dressed in her favourite colour pink. Kate proved true to her word and when she invited little Mila Sneddon and her family to the Queen’s official Edinburgh home, wore an ME+EM outfit that matched the four-year-old’s dress. The outgoing little girl who is battling cancer has captured the duchess’ heart and when they met she told the youngster she wanted to give her a “big squeezy cuddle”. Mila was featured in an iconic picture from Kate’s lockdown photographic project and came to symbolise isolation during the pandemic after she was pictured kissing her home’s kitchen window as her father stood outside.  The little girl is undergoing chemotherapy for leukaemia and was photographed separated from her father during the first lockdown, after he had to go to work and could not risk bringing coronavirus into the family home in Falkirk.Kate and Mila had talked on the phone after the image was among  selected for the duchess’ Hold Still exhibition and book and agreed to meet up. The pair met at the Palace of Holyroodhouse and when Kate walked into the room the little girl the face of the little girl, who was joined by her parents, lit up.  “Hi Mila, look at you, Kate said. I want to give you a big squeezy cuddle, it’s so nice to meet you in person. The four-year-old stood up as did her father and mother Scott and Lynda Sneddon and her big sister Jodi. Kate praised the little girl who was dressed head-to-toe in pink with matching headband, dress and shoes. She said: “I love your dress, can you do a little twirl - and your shoes.”  The four-year-old spun round for the future Queen before running over to her father. The couple are carrying out an extensive tour of Scotland in William’s role as Lord High Commissioner to the General Assembly of the Church of Scotland.  During their visit to the Balfour Hospital in Kirkwall, William praised trauma nurse Dr Tariro Gandiya: “It must be reassuring to know we are all in this together.” The Cambridges are known by their Scottish title the Earl and Countess of Strathearn when north of the border, and Kate wore a Strathearn tartan scarf and a coat by Massimo Dutti for the visit.FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnKate Middleton, Duchess of CambridgeRoyal Family

story: NewsopinionMirror Book Club reviews Amol Rajan, Richard Osman, David Mitchell, Meriel SchindlerThis week we review Rethink: Leading Voices On Le After Crisis And How We Can Make A Better World, edited by Amol Rajan, Us Three, by Ruth Jones, The Lost Cafe Schindler by Meriel Schindler, The Thursday Murder Club by Richard Osman, Utopia Avenue by David Mitchell and Project Hail Mary by Andy WeirmirrorShareCommentsByCharlotte Heathcote:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsopinionJoin the Mirror Book Club today" %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeRichard Osman and Amol Rajan are two celebrity names in this weekaposs Mirror Book Club reviews. Rajan, known for stints co-hosting the One Show and as a judge on Mastercher, has edited a collection of essays looking at what le could be like after the Covid crisis - including one by Pope Francis. While Osmanaposs novel is a delight from start to finish, says our reviewer. For all that and more - read on. And donapost forget to join the Mirror Book Club. Rethink: Leading Voices On Le After Crisis And How We Can Make A Better World, by Amol RajanBBC Books, £. Will Covid- prove to be a global ‘reset’ moment  That’s the hope that runs through Rethink, a star-studded collection of  short essays edited by Amol Rajan. He says that “we are living through one of history’s epoch shts” in which ecological devastation, a technological revolution, and a sht in global power towards China and the East are rapidly transforming societies across the globe. So how can we build back better from the pandemic and tackle the biggest problems we face at the same time  An impressive list of contributors share their ideas. What is your view  Have your say in the comment section  They include Pope Francis who urges us to stop ignoring the poor, and the Dalai Lama on seeking peace of mind. Prince Charles explores the inextricable link between the health and wellbeing of people and the planet, and Jarvis Cocker calls for an ­“environmental revolution” with “fallow years for the planet”. Physicist Carlo Rovelli argues that instead of nations competing with one another or fighting, resources must be pooled globally. The wide range of writers emphasises just how much Covid- has impacted everyone, irrespective of background. And there’s a great deal of common ground here with many contributors arguing that we must all become more active and cooperative citizens.  If Rethink has a weakness, it’s that the long list of contributors leaves little space for developing ideas in detail. Nevertheless, this thought-provoking and erse collection of voices articulates the greatest challenges we face and shares bright ideas about how best to address them. By HUSTON GILMORE Us Three, by Ruth Jones Black Swan, £. Lana, Judith and Catrin celebrate leaving school with a Greek holiday that changes their lives. Judith uncovers disturbing truths about her father’s history, while a local man breaks Catrin’s heart – but she hasn’t heard the last of him. As we follow the women for the next three decades, Ruth Jones tells a warm, witty story of enduring friendship. By ANNE CATER The Lost Cafe Schindler, by Meriel Schindler Hodder  Stoughton, £  In this compelling and beautully written account, Meriel Schindler traces her Jewish ancestors’ experiences across two tumultuous centuries. And she tells a remarkable and inspiring story that attests to the strength and compassion of the human spirit in overcoming the tragedy of persecution. Meriel’s story begins with the death of her father Kurt in . She found him dficult and untrustworthybut, after his death, she visited his isolated rundown cottage and discovered a treasure trove of family papers and photographs. As she began to piece the family history together, she decided to embark on a journey through Austria, Italy and the US to fill in the gaps, tracing family members and trawling through archives. Those archives take her back to th century Bohemia when her ancestors were tavern keepers, though the Schindlers moved to Austria after Jews were offered equal citizenship. In , her grandfather Hugo and great-uncle Erich opened Cafe Schindler, renowned for live jazz, dancing and apple strudel. But, in , Hitler seized power. Hugo was attacked on Kristallnacht and, though he escaped to England, there is moving testimony from Meriel’s great-aunt, awaiting deportation to a Nazi death camp . By the end, Meriel has a better understanding of her troubled father. This fascinating family history also reminds us why we must remain vigilant to prevent evil overwhelming decency. By EDWARD ARGYLE The Thursday Murder Club, by Richard Osman Penguin, £.  The Thursday Murder Club are Elizabeth, Joyce, Ibrahim and Ron who live in a retirement village, a former convent owned by villainous Ian Ventham, who plans to dig up the nuns’ graveyard to build more homes. Then his builder is murdered. Someone will go to any s to save the graveyard and the friends won’t rest until they find out why. A delight from start to finish. By CHARLOTTE HEATHCOTE Utopia Avenue, by David Mitchell Sceptre, £. Follow the rise and demise of Utopia Avenue in this fast-paced read. They are bassist Dean, haunted by abuse gted guitarist Jasper, tormented by a knocking sound in his head folk pianist Elf, hamstrung by heartache and gruff drummer Grf. There are cameos from Bowie, Hendrix and Brian Jones – and a devastating event that changes everything. By CHARLOTTE HEATHCOTE Project Hail Mary, by Andy Weir Del Rey, £ Former software engineer Andy Weir struck it big with his bestseller The Martian which was made into a film starring Matt Damon. This time, Weir’s hero is Ryland Grace, another wise-cracking astronaut, who wakes as the only survivor of a mission to save mankind. Although Grace’s memory is patchy at first, flashbacks reveal that an algae-like creature is depleting the sun’s energy, putting Earth’s food supply and millions of lives at risk. Grace has been sent to study the one star that seems unaffected by the scourge and report back to Earth. But his is a lonely suicide mission, though he can’t remember why, with only enough fuel for a one-way trip and no way of knowinghis findings will reach Earth safely. The book kicks into high gear when Grace crosses paths with an alien le form on the same mission. In classic buddy comedy style, Grace and Rocky complement each other’s strengths and shortcomings as they work together to save their planets. This joyous space romp is a smart and satisfying ode to the power of science and the ties that bind us. By LIJA KRESOWATY Join the Mirror Book Club We have a brand-new book of the month – All The Lonely People by Mike Gayle. Join us at facebook groups mirrorbookclub where we are giving away  copies to members.In phone calls to his daughter in Australia, widower Hubert Bird paints a picture of the perfect retirement, packed with fun and friendship. But he is lying. He hardly sees a soul. So when his daughter announces she’s coming to visit, Hubert faces a race against time to make his real le resemble his fake le. facebook groups mirrorbookclub @MirrorBookClubFOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnMirror Book ClubAndy WeirRuth Jones

More than  cases of the new strain have been identied across the country. Known as VUI-MAY- , the iant was first detected in Thailand in people who had travelled from Egypt, Public Health England confirmed. It was designated as a iant under investigation on May  on the basis of the mutation profile and increased importation from a widening international area. There is currently no evidence that this iant causes more severe disease or renders the vaccines any less effective. PHE is carrying out laboratory testing to better understand the impact of the mutations on the behaviour of the virus.  The organisation did not disclose where the cases had been detected but said test and trace has been used to limit the spread.While scientists keep an eye on the new strain, the Indian iant has quickly become the dominant version of coronavirus in the UK. story: NewsOne of Britains filthiest homes goes on sale for £, - after being left to rot for five yearsDiscarded toys, rotting food, dirty rags, rusty pots, and a bathroom with an unexplained leather chair – all yours for a generous six-figure summirrorShareCommentsByJoe PagnelliLaurie Churchman:,  MAY NewsOne of Britain’s filthiest homes will go under the hammer for £, – after it was abandoned and left to rot " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA filthy home cluttered with rubbish and rotting food is being offered for sale as seen for £,. The property was abandoned five years ago. Now, an auction house has put the exciting three-bed home up with the six-figure guide price – adding that it is in need of refurbishment. Auction House South Yorkshire said the home will be sold as seen, with no explanation for its mucky condition. The terraced home, nestled in the Hillsborough suburb of Sheffield, comes fully furnished – with rubbish, rotting food, and heaps of bin bags scattered in every room. The new owner will have to get their hands dirty.  The three-storey house boasts a cellar on the lower ground level, a kitchen and living room on the ground floor, three bedrooms and family bathroom. The new owner will also be treated to a erse selection of discarded toys and dirty rags. The kitchen features a stained cooker, rusty pots and pans, and a bottle of washing up liquid – which, surprisingly, appears to have been opened. Wallpaper in the top bedroom has been stripped off to reveal a rustic brick look. The shared bathroom is certainly unique – it has been fitted with a bath as well as a leather chair, and comes with an old toilet roll. The listing adds the property is just a stone’s throw away from an array of bars, restaurants and shops, as well as a tram and bus stop with links to the city centre.  But there was shock when the property was posted on social media in its soiled state.Craig Beresford, commenting on Facebook, quipped: “Hope furnitureaposs NOT included.”Mitch Wood said it would be better to get the wrecking ball out and knock [the] lot down”. Some people were more hopeful. Elyse Maria Bingham joked she had finally found her forever home.  She commented: “After having some setbacks and a few hurdles to jump over, weaposve finally bagged our forever home.” Itaposs not the first time a seriously grimy house has been up for sale.A property in Birmingham with unmade beds, a rubbish-strewn living room, piles of washing up in the sink and a filthy bathroom was put on the market in . Grim pictures of the house, which was on the market for £,, show it in a severe state of neglect with every room covered in discarded clothes, food and rubbish.It sold for its asking price despite the shocking snaps – before mysteriously appearing back on the market.Earlier this year, a home which came with an assortment of terrying plastic housemates was put on the market sale in the US.The three-bedroom duplex in South Lake Tahoe was said to have great income property potential – and it was put up for sale as-is. That meant the lucky new owner also bought more than a dozen creepy female mannequins dressed in sparkly gowns and wigs.FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd Comment

Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA man has beaten a billion to one odds after he found two incredibly rare lobsters - at a fishmongers in a landlocked county of Britain. Joseph Lee, , is a caterer and was shopping at Makro Wholesale, a cash and carry, when he stopped by the fishmongers to peruse their wares. When there he couldnapost believe his eyes, as he saw two orange Canadian lobsters - which are so rare that just one in  million are ever caught, making the odds of finding two of them one in a billion. Joseph then approached the fishmonger, in landlocked Leicester, and convinced him not to sell the lobsters, which were listed for £. - but instead donate them to an aquarium. Joseph said: I went in to do my usual shopping for my catering business. I saw these two orange lobsters from a distance and thought they were toys because thataposs the only time Iaposve seen them orange apart from when theyaposre cooked. I knew they wouldnapost have put cooked lobsters in there because you need to keep lobsters in a special tank with flowing water below seven degrees. I thought someone was having a joke and had put a couple of orange toy lobsters in the tank.  I got closer and noticed they were alive. I couldnapost believe my eyes. Iaposve been going to Makro for ten years and used to be a fishmonger myself but I have never seen anything like that before. Rob the fishmonger told me they were really, really rare lobsters and to get one in the tank was a one in  million chance so the chances of having two are one in a billion. It is like getting struck by lightning three times and surviving each time. To have not just one but two in the tank is unimaginable. The dad-of-two, from Leicester, decided to try and save the lobsters from being sold so spoke to the store manager who agreed to donate them to an aquarium. He said: I couldnapost bare the thought that these extremely rare creatures would end up on someoneaposs plate. I spoke to the manager of the catering ision who said they would donate them to a Sea Le Centre. Itaposs just incredible to see two of these amazingly coloured lobsters. Iaposm glad theyaposve been saved so they can be enjoyed by people. Live lobsters normally have dark brown or grey colouring which makes it easier for them to camouflage in the wild. They only turn orange after they are cooked, making the sight of two with a carrot-coloured exoskeleton even more rare. Makro store manager Anthony Burrage said: We have donated them to Birmingham Sea Le centre. After they arrived in the store from our delivery partners we realised they were unique and not the norm we called our Quality Assurance department and they did the rest. should not consider this current position acceptable particularly when its tourism sector requires such crucial support.#Take Royal Deeside for instance the fact there is no signage highlighting the way to Balmoral # a really important site for Scotland # is just not good enough.#I understand brown tourism signs are really expensive but it is really important too.#I believe that AWPR signage is critical to supporting the bounce back of north-east attractions and would help to reignite our visitor economy.#As we see the critical international trade come back again # as we will one day # we need to help ourselves.#Mr Hawkins, who previously ran the tourist attractions of Blackpool pleasure beach, highlighted brown signs remained in parts of Aberdeen, but were yet to be put up on the new dual carriageway around the the city.However, hopes of a helping hand from government towards the cost of the pricey posts were dashed when the Scottish roads body reiterated it would be for destinations to foot the bill.A Transport Scotland spokesman said: “The onus is on the inidual visitor attractions to apply for signage, where they meet the criteria set out in the relevant guidance, and approvals will be determined by the location of the proposed signage.“The costs of the signage will be dictated by the size of the sign required and the tourist attraction would be expected to fund the cost.”Mr Hawkins said the suggestion was #surprising# given the #suffering# endured by the tourism industry throughout the pandemic and called for ministers to look at introducing the signs as part of a #strategic economic approach#.He added: #Passing the parcel of costs to the tourism operators does not seem to be a productive way to go about this.#It is fair to say that some operators including charitable organisations such as the National Trust For Scotland would not be in a position to take this cost and to procure such signage.#The completion of the AWPR without tourist directional signage is unacceptable and is not representative of all other towns and cities within the UK.#The National Trust For Scotland is sounding out support for their calls # but has already won the backing of the north-east tourist board.Visit Aberdeenshire chief executive Chris Foy said the signs could perhaps uncover hidden gems which would prompt visitors to come back to the area.“We welcome consideration of any initiative that can help to reignite and sustain the visitor economy, and make it easier for visitors to discover the north-east,# he said.“Even in an age of satnav and smart phones, the recognisable brown signs can be an effective way finder for many visitors, and can also promptvisits to explore more attractions.”And Aberdeen City Council # keen to highlight the recently-refurbished art gallery, #jewel in the crown# beach and other attractions hoped to pull visitors off the fast track of the A # is also keen to take the idea to the Scottish Government.But onlythe initiative was to come for free.Conservative leader on the council Ryan Houghton, who controls the purse strings as city growth convener, said: “Anything that supports tourism within Aberdeen and Aberdeenshire is something that the council welcomes.“Alongside the National Trust For Scotland, we would be happy to lobby the Scottish Government # which controls the AWPR # to ensure appropriate road signage is put in place to highlight the many tourism attractions that are available throughout the north-east region.“I am confident that should Transport Scotland agree to fund appropriate road signage, then the local authorities would quickly move to ensure these signs were put up in appropriate places to encourage tourists to visit the many worthwhile attractions that the north-east offers.#As the huge bypass was being completed, Trump International complained about the Menie Estate golf course being #cut off# due to a lack of signs.Brown signs highlighting the north coastal route, towards Newburgh and Cruden Bay on the A, have been erected on the A Balmedie to Tipperty road, which built alongside the £bn bypass.For as little as £. a month you can access all of long-awaitedto a major tournament – are almost upon us.Having played for the national team at the  World Cup in Argentina, I hope the current crop of players involved savour the experience and make the country proud.There is nothing like playing for your country in a European Championships or a World Cup, it’s a great honour.How I found I was in the squad in  was also memorable.It was a few weeks before the tournament started and I was at a dinner at a hotel in Glasgow with the manager Ally MacLeod.Ally was the main speaker at this dinner and after his speech I went to the toilet.He came in as well, stood beside me and said #go and do me a favour, phone your dad and tell him you’re going to Argentina to play in the World Cup for Scotland#.It was totally surreal, I was standing there mesmerised really and it was a bizarre setting to find out.Ally told me not to tell anyone except my dad, because he didn’t want it getting out, so I phoned my dad and swore him to secrecy that night.Then I got up the next morning and Ally was in the papers saying I’d been selected! But that was just Ally.I was the last player to get into the squad. There was debate about whether it would be me, Ian Wallace from Coventry or Andy Gray from Aston Villa and that was how I found out.Although we didn’t do as well as we wanted in Argentina, featuring in the tournament is still something I’m proud of.I only played  minutes of one game and when anybody asks about it I always say I was unbeaten in the World Cup game I played#unfortunately that game was against Iran, who we should have beaten rather than drawing -.I had a lot of great days with Aberdeen and won the Premier Division, Scottish Cup and League Cup, but to play for Scotland in a tournament was the biggest honour of my career.The players who get to wear the jersey this summer will feel the same I would imagine.For them it may be even more special, because there have been many good players over the last  years who haven’t had the chance.Since Steve Clarke became Scotland manager, there seems to be a lot more optimism around the national team and that’s only increased since qualying for the Euros.Under Clarke, Scotland have found an identity.Since Craig Brown’s tenure as manager, there have been occasions where Scotland have looked rudderless.But that isn’t the case under Steve # there seems to be a clear plan and I think the current manager is very similar to Craig in a number of ways.Craig was always well-prepared and didn’t leave anything to chance.His teams were always organised, he altered his tactics depending on the opposition and was very thorough and methodical when he did the job and Steve is similar. Hopefully he guides us through the group stage this summer.For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.
